questions.text: A 70-year-old male was found in a disoriented state in his apartment by his son. He has a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has a dry tongue and appears extremely dehydrated. Serum glucose is found to be 848mg/gl. What is the immediate next step in the management of his condition?
questions.solution:
This old man with a serum glucose of 848mg/dl and a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus most likely has developed hyperosmolar hyperglycemic syndrome, likely secondary to an underlying infection. The patient has signs of dehydration like a dry tongue - so the immediate next step in his management is to give him IV isotonic saline. This allows an overall improvement in his hydration status and reduces levels of stress hormones, which will allow further management of his condition with insulin and potassium infusion(if needed). 

HHS is commonly seen in older adults suffering from type 2 diabetes mellitus predominantly. Patients can present with the following features:

  • Polyuria
  • Polydipsia
  • confusion, drowsiness
  • Altered sensorium, coma
  • Seizures
  • Severe dehydration
  • concomitant infection, MI, stroke

The following lab values are seen: 

  • Blood glucose of 600-1200 mg/dl
  • Serum osmolality > 350 mOsm/L
  • Prerenal azotemia due to dehydration
  • Pseudohyponatremia may be seen due to hyperglycemia
  • Normal pH and ketones (Some cases can have mild ketonuria).

The mainstay of management is fluid replacement, IV regular insulin, along with potassium replacement. Heparin can be given prophylactically as volume contraction can increase the risk of venous thrombosis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old chronic alcoholic patient was driving under alcohol influence and met with an accident. He is admitted with a shaft of femur fracture. On the third day of admission,  he develops severe restlessness and altered sensorium. He has visual and tactile hallucinations.  Which of the following drugs should be avoided for the management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of altered sensorium with visual and tactile hallucinations following alcohol withdrawal is suggestive of delirium tremens. Antipsychotics like Clozapine are avoided in the management of delirium tremens as they lower the seizure threshold, placing the patient at a greater risk for developing alcohol-withdrawal seizures.

Antipsychotics are used to manage the psychotic symptoms in cases of delirium but in cases of delirium associated with alcohol withdrawal the use of antipsychotics is not recommended. All antipsychotics except pimavanserin are associated with an increased risk for seizures, with clozapine having a dose-dependent seizure risk.

Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that occurs during alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops within 3-4 days of the last drink. It has symptoms of both delirium and alcohol withdrawal. In the above scenario, delirium tremens precipitated as the patient was admitted into the hospital ward and couldn't consume alcohol for three days. The clinical features of delirium tremens are:

  • Altered sensorium with disorientation
  • Perceptual distortions, most frequently tactile or visual hallucinations
  • Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, insomnia, hypertension, and sweating
  • Fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from agitation to lethargy
  • Altered sleep-wake cycle

Benzodiazepines such as diazepam (intravenously) or chlordiazepoxide (orally every 4 hours) are given in order to deal with the symptoms. It is also recommended to administer thiamine in patients with alcohol-related disorders to prevent Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. Patients that do not respond even to high-dose benzodiazepines, should be administered Propofol or Dexmedetomidine in closely-monitored doses.

Note: Haloperidol is the only recommended antipsychotic given in cases of severe psychosis in Delirium tremens.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with recent confusion and difficulty in doing daily activities of living. She also has recent urinary incontinence and walks with a magnetic gait. She has a past history of meningitis. Which of the following is the definitive management of her condition?
questions.solution:
The classic triad of dementia(difficulties in activities of daily living and confusion), hypokinetic magnetic gait, and urinary incontinence seen in this patient suggest normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). The definitive treatment of this condition is ventriculoperitoneal shunting to reduce the intracranial pressure on the surrounding brain tissue.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a communicating hydrocephalus caused by delayed resorption of cerebrospinal fluid. Meningeal scarring is seen in some patients, due to previous history of meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or head trauma.

It presents with the characteristic triad of

  • Dementia (mostly executive function),
  • Ataxic or apractic gait, and
  • Urinary incontinence (sometimes urgency too).

It is classified as idiopathic (primary) or symptomatic (secondary) occurring due to prior brain infection, injury, radiation, or hemorrhage. 

The etiology is poorly understood but is thought to be related to the hyperdynamic flow of CSF in the aqueduct, reduced compliance of the subarachnoid space, increased CSF pulse pressure, and reduced reabsorption of CSF. 

Diagnosis: 

  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the Sylvian fissures can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy due to the propped open (so-called “boxcarring”) appearance.
  • CSF parameters are normal except for the high range of pressure.
  • Another confirmatory test performed is the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) tap test, which shows marked improvement of symptoms with spinal fluid removal.

Treatment: Ventriculoperitoneal shunting: It is done to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Complications of the shunting procedure include shunt obstruction, infection, intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage, malposition or breakage of the shunt, etc.

Other options:

Option B - Periodic lumbar punctures can help reduce the symptoms in pseudotumour cerebri but have no role in the management of NPH.

Option C - Levodopa-carbidopa is used in the management of Parkinsons disease which presents with tremors, rigidity, akinesia and postural instability.

Option D - Acetylcholine esterase inhibitors like rivastigmine, galantamine are used in the management of Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought with complaints of progressive memory deficits and concentration problems. On examination, he is only oriented to person and scores 22 on the mini mental state examination. History reveals unintentional weight loss and arthralgia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has progressive neurological symptoms with a history of unintentional weight loss and arthralgias. The probable diagnosis is Whipple's disease.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by Tropheryma whipplei. It primarily causes malabsorption along with the central nervous system and cardiac problems.

The disease has an insidious onset, characterized by arthralgias, weight loss, chronic diarbrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. Long term disease can cause cardiac and neurological complications.

Important CNS manifestations in Whipple's disease are:

  • Personality and mood changes
  • Progressive supranuclear ophthalmoplegia
  • Focal neurologic presentations
  • Oculomasticatory myorrhythmia - an unusual combination of rhythmic eye and jaw movements which is pathognomonic of Whipple's disease.

Whipple's disease associated with CNS symptoms has a poor prognosis.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is made through a biopsy which shows PAS-positive macrophages in the small intestine. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) and polymerase chain reaction are other sensitive investigations. 

The treatment regimen includes ceftriaxone or meropenem. It is followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 12 months.

The most common CNS manifestation associated with Whipple’s disease is progressive dementia.

Other options:

Option B: Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy where there is an excessive inflammatory response to gluten and its breakdown product, gliadin. This leads to inflammatory infiltration of the lamina propria which subsequently impairs various nutrient absorption. Clinically, it presents as a malabsorption syndrome with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss.

Option C: Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies that impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF) that is released from the parietal cells, which is required for the uptake of vitamin B12. These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells, and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells.

Option D: Tropical sprue is another malabsorption disorder seen as diarrhea, steatorrhea, nutritional deficiencies, and weight loss. It is prevalent in some tropical areas hence the name. Though the exact etiology is still unaccounted for, it is mostly attributed to infectious agents considering its response to antibiotics. It is diagnosed by a small intestinal biopsy which shows a close resemblance to that seen in celiac disease. Broad-spectrum antibiotics along with folic acid supplementation forms the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is brought with confusion and dizziness since the last 12 hours. Over the last 2-3 days she has had right upper quadrant pain, and fever and now has a yellowish tinge on her conjunctiva. BP is 90/60mmhg. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presented with right upper quadrant pain, fever, jaundice with altered mental status, and hypovolemia has all the components of the Reynolds pentad. This patient most likely has ascending cholangitis, likely secondary to obstruction by a gallstone. 

Primary ascending cholangitis is a life-threatening condition caused by an ascending bacterial infection of the intra- and extrahepatic ducts with secondary blockage of the biliary tracts. It affects both men and women aged 50 to 60 years. Charcot triad describes cholangitis as clinical findings of fever, right upper abdominal pain, and jaundice. When the patient also has altered mental status and hypovolemia it is termed as the Reynold's pentad. 

A liver biopsy shows cholestasis within the hepatic parenchyma and neutrophils involving the bile duct lumen. 

Presence of the Reynold's pentad has a high mortality rate and treatment is urgent surgery to restore bile flow. PAtients are also given concomitant antibiotics and IV fluids. 

Other options:

Option A: Subphrenic abscesses occur in the space that lies between the right lobe of the liver and the diaphragm. It is limited posteriorly by the anterior layer of the coronary and the right triangular ligaments, and to the left by the falciform ligament. Common causes of abscess here are perforating cholecystitis, a perforated duodenal ulcer and a duodenal cap ‘blow-out’ following gastrectomy and appendicitis. This patient has no such history

Option B: Cholangiocarcinoma presents as painless jaundice with unintentional weight loss. This patient's presentation is more acute and makes cholangitis more likely.

Option C: Hydrops gall bladder occurs due to an obstruction in the gallbladder leading to accumulation of mucous and distension of the gall bladder. It presents with right upper quadrant pain and doesn't present with acute symptoms in a short time frame.

questions.text: A 76-year-old male patient receiving multiple medications in the medicine ward is suddenly fighting with the nurses as he is unaware of where he is and wants to go home. On examination,  the patient is confused, argumentative and is constantly trying to get out of the ward. Which of the following measures should be taken next?

choices.text: Prescribe a benzodiazepine to calm him down
Prescribing the corner bed to reduce disturbances to other patients
Using  soft braces to tether him to the bed to prevent fall injury
Remind him of his location and get him back into bed

questions.solution:
This patient in the medicine ward with sudden onset of confusion and violent behavior is likely in acute delirium induced by poly-pharmacy. The next step in the management of this patient would be to attempt to reorient the patient and gently try to get him back into bed. 

Delirium is a form of altered mental status manifesting commonly as inattention and confusion. Sometimes patients can get violent due to a severe lack of perception of their surroundings. It is commonly seen in elderly patients receiving multiple medications, or in post-op patients. Delirium is usually secondary to an underlying condition and it should be corrected first. Apart from that, reorientation protocols should be practiced to allow the patients to reorient themselves. This includes:

  1. Avoiding polypharmacy wherever possible. Always monitor a patient's current drugs before adding a new one and eliminate any that can cause delirium. Examples of such drug classes include First generation histamine blockers, Benzodiazepines, and drugs for insomnia.
  2. Correct any underlying electrolyte disorders
  3. Reorient the patient. Both the family and the healthcare staff should constantly reorient the patient.
  4. Provide a dark and quiet environment at night to ensure uninterrupted sleep. During the day they should be in well-lit areas to allow them to be aware of the passage of time.
  5. Patients at risk of delirium are also at risk of falls, so they should be placed directly in the nursing staff's line of sight to allow monitoring. Corner beds or secluded areas are usually away from the line of sight of the nursing station and so that should be avoided. (Option B)
  6. Avoid benzodiazepines as they can further exacerbate delirium. (Option A)
  7. Restraints must be avoided unless the patient is very uncooperative. The patient must be first attempted to be calmed down. (Option C)

questions.text:
A patient is brought to the casualty with reduced responsiveness after consuming multiple illicit substances in a party. He only moans in response to painful stimuli and is not oriented to time, place and person. His respiratory rate is 9 breaths per minute and he is not responsive to naloxone administration. Which of the following drugs could he have likely consumed?
  1. Phencyclidine
  2. Amphetamines
  3. Benzodiazepines
  4. Heroin
  5. Barbiturates
questions.solution:
This patient with features of reduced responsiveness and low respiratory rate with complete disorientation to time, place, and person has consumed a drug that reduces the CNS responsiveness. He is also not responsive to naloxone administration. Out of the options listed, only benzodiazepines and barbiturates are likely to be the drugs he might have consumed.

Benzodiazepines, barbiturates and heroin can all present with reduced responsiveness and respiratory disturbances. However, heroin overdose is reversed by naloxone, which is a opioiod antagonist. Since this patient is not responding to naloxone, heroin can be ruled out as a cause of his symptoms. 

The other drugs listed such as amphetamines and phencyclidine are both stimulants and present with symptoms of increased activity, sympathetic activation and reduced need for sleep. Phencyclidine in addition to this also has a characteristic finding of nystagmus. As these symptoms are not seen in this patient, they can also be ruled out. 

Benzodiazepine toxicity is treated with flumazenil, barbiturate overdoses are however only managed symptomatically as there is no antidote for barbiturate toxicity.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty with a 10-day history of increasing confusion. Physical examination shows a startle myoclonus. Over the past 12 months, he has had progressive memory deficits. This patient had a VP shunt insertion post meningitis 5 years ago at the same hospital. Lumbar puncture showed normal glucose counts. 4 other patients of this hospital after that procedure have had similar complaints in the past 6 months. What is the likely etiology of his condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has presented with symptoms of rapidly progressive neurological and memory deficits with current complaints of confusion. 4 other patients with similar complaints make a nosocomial cause the likely etiology. The rapid progression of symptoms makes Prion disease caused by accumulation of misfolded protein the likely cause of this condition. The source of the prion infection could have been the surgical equipment that was not adequately sterilized. 

The proteins that make up the prions (PrP) are present even normally in the cells. This normal form, PrPc, is in a predominantly α-helical configuration and is sensitive to proteases. However, the prions (infectious form) are in an abnormal β-pleated configuration and are called PrPSc. This pathological form is not degradable by proteases and converts the normal form- PrPc to the abnormal form- PrPSc. This abnormal protein gets deposited as plaques and degeneration of surrounding neuronal and glial tissue occurs characterized by intracellular vacuoles, leading to a characteristic spongiform encephalopathy. There is no associated inflammatory response to these agents. 

Four types of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease have been described:

  • Sporadic (sCJD): Most common;
  • Variant (vCJD): Bovine spongiform encephalopathy (mad cow disease), Kuru;
  • Familial (fCJD): These individuals carry a PrPc mutation and include Gerstmann-Sträussler- Scheinker syndrome and fatal familial insomnia;
  • Iatrogenic (iCJD): Maybe seen occurring after corneal transplantation, liver transplantation, use of contaminated neurosurgical instruments, use of cadaver-derived hormones, or stereotactic depth electrodes. 

Clinically, CJD presents with predominantly CNS manifestations with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus (startle myoclonus is common), ataxia, akinetic mutism, visual disturbances, and pyramidal/extrapyramidal dysfunction. Insomnia, apathy, and other behavioral abnormalities may be seen. 

CSF is predominantly normal but may show a positive assay for 14-3-3 protein. EEG may show periodic triphasic or multiphasic sharp-wave complexes seen as spikes or spike-wave patterns. MRI on FLAIR sequencing and diffusion-weighted imaging will show increased intensity in the basal ganglia region and a characteristic 'cortical ribboning', in sporadic CJD. Diagnosis of CJD can be established on brain biopsy either by measuring PrPSc or by demonstrating the characteristic neuropathological features of spongiform encephalopathy.

Management is mainly supportive as the disease is usually fatal within a year of the onset of symptoms. 

Other options:

Option A: Chronic bacterial meningitis causes features of raised ICP and is associated with a decreased glucose count in the CSF. This patient's startle myoclonus with a history of a neurological procedure makes a diagnosis of Prion disease more likely.

Option C: Blockage of the shunt system presents with features of raised ICP as there is no outlet for drainage of CSF. This patient's only symptoms are progressive memory deficits with a history of VP shunt insertion. This makes a prion disease the likely etiology. 

Option D: Surgical error during the procedure could have presented more acutely and not after 5 years.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the casualty with an altered sensorium. He has had a non-remitting fever of 102 degrees Fahrenheit over the last 2 weeks. BP is 100/80mmHg. On 2D echo, vegetations are seen on the mitral valve. What is the likely etiology of his altered sensorium?
questions.solution:
This patient has altered sensorium in the setting of fever, and vegetations on 2D ECHO. The most probable diagnosis for this patient would be infective endocarditis (IE) with septic emboli to the brain leading to infections and the symptoms of altered sensorium. 

Cardiac manifestations of IE:

  • Presence of new regurgitant murmurs
  • Congestive heart failure due to valve dysfunction
  • Perivalvular abscesses and intracardiac fistulae - This is caused due to the extension of infection beyond the valves and into the adjacent myocardial tissue
  • Conduction system defects- due to the damage of the interventricular septum by the abscess.
  • Embolization of coronary arteries

Noncardiac manifestations of IE are:

  • Arterial emboli- causing pain of ischemia of the organs
  • Osler's nodes -are painful, red, nodular lesions usually located in the pads of the fingers and toes
  • Roth's spots- retinal hemorrhages with a pale center
  • Janeway lesions- In contrast to Osler's nodes, these are faint, red, painless macules on palms and soles. They occur as a result of septic embolization and are commonly associated with staphylococcal IE.
  • Splenic abscess
  • Cerebral abscess
  • Immune-complex mediated glomerulonephritis
  • Positivity for rheumatoid factor
  • Petechiae on oral and conjunctival mucosa
  • Splinter subungual hemorrhages-painless, dark red lines in the nailbed.
  • Mycotic aneurysms
  • Splenomegaly

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a history of chronic alcohol comsuption presented to the casualty with confusion, ataxia and diplopia. What is the protocol to treat this patient?

choices.text: Thiamine injection followed by glucose infusion

questions.solution:
Diplopia, ataxia and confusion in a patient with chronic alcohol consumption  is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy. The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

  1. Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by global confusion, truncal ataxia, ophthalmoplegia and horizontal nystagmus.
  2. Korsakoff psychosis: Symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include memory loss and confabulation
  3. Beriberi: It can be either -
    • Dry beriberi: Sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, muscle weakness
    • Wet beriberi: Tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure

questions.text: What is the earliest symptom of hepatic encephalopathy?
questions.solution:
The earliest symptom of hepatic encephalopathy is an alteration in sleep pattern.

Other signs and symptoms of hepatic encephalopathy include: 

  • Asterixis also called the flapping tremor
  • Mood changes and inappropriate behavior
  • Disorientation and confusion

questions.text: A 57 year old male is brought with complaints of progressive loss of cognitive function. His symptoms began 2 years ago, and he had a noticeable worsening again 1 year ago and 6 months ago with progressive worsening of symptoms. He is oriented only to person and place but not time. He has a past history of diabetes and hypertension. Which of the following investigations should be done next?
questions.solution:
In the given patient, who is a known case of hypertension and diabetes mellitus, now presenting with stepwise deteriorating cognitive function with 3 different discrete time periods where he had a noticeable worsening of symptoms, the likely diagnosis is vascular dementia. Diagnosis of vascular dementia is usually made by finding lesions via an MRI of the brain.

Vascular dementia is the second most prevalent form of dementia, after Alzheimer disease. It includes any dementia which is primarily caused by a cerebrovascular disease or impaired cerebral blood flow. Any cause of ischemic stroke (like atheroembolism), intracerebral hemorrhage, or subarachnoid hemorrhage can cause vascular dementia if the underlying injury to the brain is severe enough. Aside from a clinical stroke, cerebral small vessel diseases such as arteriosclerosis and cerebral amyloid angiopathy can also lead to vascular dementia.

The patient will likely have a vascular risk factor (hypertension, diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, tobacco use or atrial fibrillation), a history of prior stroke, or transient ischemic attack. There will usually be a stepwise decline in the patient's mental state due to a series of unrecognized strokes. Executive functions (such as planning and organization) are likely to be affected more and early in the disease course. This is in contrast to Alzheimer's disease, where there's a slow progression and recent episodic memory is affected first.

Diagnosis is usually clinical based on the history but lesions in the brain can be visualised by an MRI. 

Treatment is mainly aimed at preventing further strokes via pharmacotherapy and supportive therapy.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with recurrent symptoms of blurred vision now presents with confusion and disorientation. The serum gamma gap is >3 g/dl and the predominant component is IgM. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's altered mental status?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status with a history of recurrent blurriness of vision. This, combined with the serum gamma gap of >3mg/dl and an IgM predominance makes Waldenstorm's Macroglobulinemia(WM) the likely diagnosis. The next step in the management of this patient's altered mental status is with plasmapheresis. 

WM is a condition characterized by monoclonal proliferation of Plasma cells that overproduces IgM. These antibodies increase the viscosity of the blood. These antibodies also lead to an increase in the serum gamma gap > 3g/dl. The treatment of choice is plasmapheresis which helps in removing the excessive IgM in the plasma thus relieving the hyperviscosity symptoms. 

Waldenström’s macroglobulinemia is a plasma cell disorder that results in increased proliferation of memory B cells. These cells produce large amounts of IgM leading to the classic hyperviscosity syndrome. Most commonly, they present with fatigue, weakness, and oozing of blood from the nasal or oral cavity.  Patients also present with anemia, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, hyperviscosity, or peripheral neuropathy. When the hyperviscosity progresses to involve the CNS, it can occlude the vessels in the CNS and can lead to altered mental status. 

Hematological examination reveals Coombs’ positive test and rouleaux fobrmation. This condition also has a greater incidence of normocytic normochromic anemia.

The hyperviscosity state can be treated by plasmapheresis. However, most patients do not require therapy unless they are symptomatic (altered mental status, anemia, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly.) It can be treated with ibrutinib which targets the activated BTK mutation. Rituximab with cyclophosphamide can also be used. 

Other options:

Option A: Chemotherapy is usually not indicated in Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia if the patient is asymptomatic. In symptomatic cases, initial treatment should be attempted with plasmapheresis first. 

Option B: IV immunoglobulin is used to treat autoimmune polyneuropathies like Guillain Barre syndrome. It has no role in Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia.

Option D: Phlebotomy is the treatment for polycythemia vera and does not have a role in Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia.

questions.text: A known patient of parkinsonism, taking levodopa for the past 2 years, presents to you with disorientation, confusion, and altered sensorium. You try to reduce the dose of levodopa but it worsens the motor symptoms and the presenting symptoms persist despite reducing the dose. Which of the following drugs is best suited for managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Clozapine is recommended in the above given clinical scenario.

The patient presents with disorientation, confusion and altered sensorium. This is suggestive of delirium. Antiparkinsonian agents are frequently implicated in causing delirium because of dopamine increase.

Decreasing the dosage of the antiparkinsonian agent has to be weighed against a worsening of motor symptoms.

Clozapine is recommended when:

  • The antiparkinsonian agents cannot be further reduced
  • Delirium persists even after reducing the dose of antiparkinsonian agents.

If a patient is not able to tolerate clozapine, alternative antipsychotic agents should be considered.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to your clinic following seizures. He has had a persistent dry cough for 6 months, and he has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He is confused and oriented only to person. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 119 mEq/L and a glucose concentration of 102 mg/dL. The hilar mass in the x-ray shown below is biopsied and reveals small cell carcinoma. Which of the following laboratory findings will not be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a chronic smoker presenting with seizures, lethargy, and altered mental status in the setting of hyponatremia and the x-ray showing an irregular, poorly demarcated mass at the right hilum is suggestive of a Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH) secondary to underlying small cell lung cancer. SIADH results in a high urine osmolality (concentrated urine) rather than a low osmolality.

SIADH can be associated with several different tumors such as that of the lung, ovaries, pancreas, and bladder. In this condition, ectopic vasopressin is produced by small-cell lung cancer, which is a neuroendocrine tumor.

Ectopic vasopressin increases the anti-diuretic property of the kidney, decreasing renal clearance and leading to SIADH. This causes increased free water retention, leading to hyponatremia (low serum osmolality) and concentration of urine, resulting in elevated urine osmolality. Water retention reduces serum osmolality, causing a transient volume expansion. This stimulates a release of ANP and BNP and reduces levels of aldosterone. Together, these processes increase urinary sodium and water excretion, thereby causing euvolemic hyponatremia.

Treatment involves the administration of conivaptan or tolvaptan (vasopressin receptor V2 antagonist), demeclocycline, and fluid restriction to less than 500 mL (although this can be difficult).

In severe cases, correction of hyponatremia is done by administering IV fluids with hypertonic normal saline along with diuretics such as furosemide (to increase free water clearance). In tumor-associated SAIDH, treatment of the underlying malignancy also helps in resolving hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought with new onset irritability and decreased concentration. He has also recently had an ataxic gait. The child is found to have an intra-abdominal mass. Examination findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis in this boy?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a dancing movement of the eyes called Opsoclonus. This in the presence of an abdominal mass should raise suspicions of a syndrome known as Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome seen in neuroblastoma. 

Neuroblastoma is a malignant tumor that is seen in young children (<5 years). It is the most common extracranial tumor of childhood. It is derived from neural crest cells of the adrenal medulla or the paravertebral sympathetic chain and is most commonly found in the abdomen. Most children have metastatic disease at the time of diagnosis. 

The common clinical features are:

  • intra-abdominal mass or paravertebral mass
  • proptosis, periorbital bruising (raccoon eyes) due to orbital metastasis
  • painless blue skin lesions (blueberry muffin syndrome) due to dissemination to the skin
  • opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome (rapid nystagmus + involuntary limb spasms)

This tumor often crosses the spine in the midline, and this can help to differentiate it from a Wilm's tumor which is mostly unilateral in nature. 

The diagnosis can be made with a combination of biochemical tests (vanillylmandelic acid [VMA], homovanillic acid [HVA], dopamine, noradrenaline) and imaging studies (CT/MRI). Staging of the tumor is done on the basis of the International Neuroblastoma Staging System. CT, bone scan, meta-iodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) scan, and bone marrow aspiration are required for accurate staging. 

Based on the stage of the tumor it is risk stratified. Low-risk patients are managed with only surgery. Intermediate-risk patients are offered surgery as well as adjuvant chemotherapy (carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, etoposide, doxorubicin). High-risk patients are managed with initial high-dose multiagent chemotherapy followed by surgery.

N-myc amplification is associated with a poor prognosis.

Other options:

Option (A): Wilm's tumor can present with an intraabdominal mass, but there is usually no involvement of the orbits or opsoclonus myoclonus.

Option (C): Rhabdomyosarcoma can be seen in the head and neck and genitourinary tract most commonly. It can involve the orbit, but would not present with opsoclonus myoclonus.

Option (D): Hepatoblastoma usually presents with nonspecific symptoms of abdominal discomfort, weight loss, and anorexia. It can also present as an abdominal mass, but it too will not have features of orbital metastasis or opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was brought in by his parents because their son was speaking to himself and had stopped going outside. At night he locks himself up in his room to do cleansing rituals for the demons. These symptoms have been present for 2 months. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has an auditory hallucination, reduced affect, and disorganised behaviour within 6 months, which is suggestive of Schizophreniform disorder.

Diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia (DSM V):

1. The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months.

2. Within this 6-month period, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms) where 2 or more of the following have to be present : 

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behaviour
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

At least one must be among the a, b, or c.

3. The rest of the 6-month period may include

  • continuing psychotic symptoms
  • prodromal symptoms preceding clear-cut psychosis
  • residual symptoms after the resolution of the psychotic symptoms

4. Residual symptoms are defined as attenuated forms of psychotic symptoms, such as

  • odd beliefs
  • magical thinking
  • ideas of reference
  • odd perceptual experiences
  • peculiar or concrete thinking
  • vague speech
  • odd behaviour
  • Negative symptoms may also be included

5. Exclusion of mood disorder & substance abuse

Note: DSM-5 does not require that delusions must be bizarre.

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty due to new onset confusion and agitation for the last 3 days. He takes diuretics for hypertension. On examination, serum sodium is found to be 121mEq/L. What should be done to manage his condition?

choices.text: Restrict water intake till Na+ levels are normalised
Administer 500ml Boluses of hypertonic saline till confusion resolves
Infusion of hypertonic saline at 1ml/kg/hr till confusion resolves

questions.solution:
This patient presenting with altered mental status with a history of diuretic use now has symptomatic hyponatremia. When Na+ levels are less than 125mEq/L, and the patient is symptomatic, the next step in management is to administer hypertonic saline infusion at 1ml/kg/hr till the confusion resolves. After this, the patient should be shifted to a slow infusion of 0.9% Normal saline at 0.5 mEq/hr. 

Hyponatremia is the term used to describe serum sodium levels less than 135mEq/L. It can be classified further based on the etiology and osmotic status of the patient:

the types of hyponatremia, as classified according to the volume status of the patient, described below: 

  • Hypovolemic hyponatremia, patients have a volume deficit due to loss of fluids rich in sodium. There is volume depletion but the depletion of sodium is relatively more than the depletion of water. This may be due to extra-renal or renal causes.In the case of extra-renal causes, there is hypovolemia due to fluid loss in conditions such as diarrhoea, vomiting, burns, etc. due to which sodium is lost along with the fluid and hence urine sodium concentration will also be low. However, in case of renal loss, the sodium is lost at the nephron level itself, causing increased urine sodium concentration, as seen in adrenal insufficiency.
  • Euvolemic hyponatremia, there is no volume depletion, but low sodium concentration relative to the total body water, as seen in conditions such as hypothyroidism and SIADH.
  • Hypervolemic hyponatremia, patients are in a condition of fluid overload. In case of fluid overload due to acute or chronic renal failure, urine sodium concentration will be high. 
    In case of fluid overload due to cirrhosis, CCF and nephrotic syndrome, urine sodium concentration will be low.

questions.text: A patient at 34 weeks of gestation is brought with decreased attention, clumsiness while walking, and headache since 12 hours. BP is found to be 190/110 mmHg. MRI of the brain shows areas of hypointensity on T1 flair in the occipital region. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient at 34 weeks of gestation now presents with altered sensorium and high blood pressure. The presence of hypointensities on T1 weighted MRIs in the occipital region makes a diagnosis of Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome the likely diagnosis. 

PRES (Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome)can occur with head injury, migraine, seizures, eclampsia and in the postpartum period. It is a hyperperfusion state with widespread segmental vasoconstriction and cerebral edema. Patients present with headaches and fluctuating neurologic signs and symptoms, especially visual symptoms.

MRI shows edema predominantly in the occipital lobes, seen as hypointensities on T1 flair. It can be generalized, but it is not confined to any single vascular territory. Ischaemia reverses completely.

Treatment is by slowly reducing the high blood pressure with IV drugs.

Other options: 

Option A: A Cerebrovascular accident can present with loss of function or weakness of limbs, signs of ataxia, or loss of sensory signaling based on the region affected due to ischemia or bleeding. However, this patient has no history of weakness, and the findings of the MRI make PRES more likely. 

Option C: Cerebral venous thrombosis presents with similar symptoms however, MRI will show a clot visible. Hypointensities in the posterior lobe is characteristic of PRES.

Option D: Subarachnoid hemorrhage can present with similar features but MRI will show a hyperintensity in the subarachnoid region on T1 flair

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient post a neurosurgical procedure. The patient opens her eyes in response to a loud voice, localizes pain, and is confused and disoriented. What is the GCS score of this patient?
questions.solution:
In this patient, GCS is E3M5V4

  • Eye-opening to loud voice - 3
  • Motor response localizes pain - 5
  • Verbal response is confused and disoriented - 4

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.
